questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents for laparoscopic appendicectomy. She had a malignant hyperthermia crisis during a prior surgery. Which of the following inhaled anesthetics would be appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Malignant hyperthermia (MH) is a life-threatening hypermetabolic state of skeletal muscle that is triggered by the volatile inhaled anesthetics-
    • Isoflurane
    • Desflurane
    • Sevoflurane
    • Depolarizing muscle relaxant succinylcholine
  • Malignant hyperthermia presents as an increase in
    • Carbon dioxide production
    • Acidosis
    • Cardiac arrhythmias
    • Muscle rigidity
    • Hyperthermia
  • Death can occur if the MH crisis is not managed appropriately and early during the episode
  • The mainstay of treatment is i.v. Dantrolene
  • Of the inhaled anesthetics, only nitrous oxide is not contraindicated in malignant hyperthermia

choices.text: Expansion of air-filled spaces in the body

questions.text: All the following are seen with Nitrous oxide except:
questions.solution:
• N2O exhibits the following two effects
  • The 'concentration effect' implies that the greater the inspired anesthetic concentration, the more rapid the rise in the alveolar concentration
  • The 'second gas effect' refers to the ability of one gas administered in a high concentration (e.g. N2O) to accelerate the uptake of another gas (e.g. halothane) that is co-administered
  • sixty-six percent of N2O in oxygen decreases the MAC of halothane to 0.29, of enflurane to 0.6, of isoflurane to 0.5, of sevoflurane to 0.66, and of desflurane to 2.8

Option A: Nitrous oxide is 35 times more soluble than nitrogen in the blood. Because of this physical property of the gas, when N2O is discontinued, the ingress of the gas into the alveoli lowers the alveolar oxygen concentration. This is called fink effect or diffusion hypoxia.

Option B: Nitrous oxide is 35 times more soluble than nitrogen in the blood; N2O will therefore cause an increase in the size of air-filled spaces (e.g. pneumothorax, intestines, air cysts in the middle ear) in the body.

Option D: 15% of patients receiving N2O will experience nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: Opioid receptors belong to which class?
questions.solution:
• Opioids bind to specific receptors located throughout the central nervous system and other tissues
  • Four major opioid receptor types have been identified: mu, kappa, delta, and sigma
  • All opioid receptors couple to G proteins binding of an agonist to an opioid receptor causes membrane hyperpolarization
  • Acute opioid effects are mediated by inhibition of adenylyl cyclase (reductions in intracellular cyclic adenosine monophosphate concentrations) and activation of phospholipase C

questions.text: CNS effect of opioid is?
questions.solution:
• Opioids reduce
    • Cerebral oxygen consumption (Option D is CORRECT)
    • Cerebral blood flow
    • Cerebral blood volume (Option C)
    • Intracranial pressure (Option B)
  • Opioids usually have almost no effects on the electroencephalogram (EEG), although large doses are associated with slow delta-wave activity
  • Stimulation of the medullary chemoreceptor trigger zone is responsible for opioid-induced nausea and vomiting (Option A)
  • Prolonged dosing of opioids can also produce "opioid-induced hyperalgesia", in which patients become more sensitive to painful stimuli

questions.text: The following local anesthetics are used for topical anaesthesia except?
questions.solution:
• Lidocaine, tetracaine, benzocaine and dibucaine are the drugs most commonly used for topical anesthesia
  • Lidocaine and tetracaine are used as →topical sprays prior to
    • endotracheal intubation to blunt the cardiovascular responses
    • prior to esophagoscopy and bronchoscopy for mucosal analgesia
  • Lidocaine plus tetracaine combination is available as a peel→which can provide topical analgesia prior to superficial dermatological procedures
  • Lidocaine patch is available which can be used → to relieve post herpetic neuralgia
  • Cocaine can also be used to provide →topical anesthesia of the nose, nasopharynx, mouth, and throat
    • It has both analgesia and vasoconstricting properties thereby decreasing surgical bleeding
  • EMLA (Eutectic Mixture of Local Anaesthetic) cream consists of a 1:1 mixture of 2.5% lidocaine and 2.5% prilocaine. EMLA can provide adequate dermal analgesia for procedures like:
    • Split thickness skin-graft harvesting
    • Venepuncture
    • laser removal of port wine stains
    • lithotripsy
    • circumcision

questions.text: The following local anesthetics are metabolized by plasma cholinesterase except?
questions.solution:
• Procaine, cocaine, tetracaine, and chloroprocaine are all amino ester compounds
  • All Amino ester compounds are hydrolysed by plasma cholinesterase (pseudocholinesterase or butyryl cholinesterase) except cocaine which is partially metabolized by hepatic carboxylesterase and partially excreted unexchanged in → the urine
  • Amino Amide local anesthetics like lidocaine, bupivacaine, ropivacaine, prilocaine are metabolized (N-dealkylation and hydroxylation) by → microsomal P-450 enzymes in the liver

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement concerning rapacuronium?
questions.solution:
• Rapacurium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant(Option C) which has a very high incidence of bronchospasm (>9%) and so it is contraindicated in asthmatics (Option B is Incorrect)
  • Because of this, it has been withdrawn from the market
  • Rapacuronium has a rapid onset and short duration of action (option A) and minimal cardiovascular side effects (Option D)

questions.text: The following are primarily dependent on kidney for excretion except?
questions.solution:
• Cis-atracurium does not depend on kidney for excretion
  • Cis-atracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination - which is spontaneous non-enzymatic degradation. So renal failure doesn't affect the clearance of cis atracurium. Hence it is the agent of choice in renal failure patients. Atracurium also undergo Hofmann elimination and so is an alternative to cis atracurium in renal failure
  • Steroidal muscle relaxants are predominantly eliminated by ultrafiltration by the glomeruli before urinary excretion
  • Doxacurium, pancuronium, and pipecuronium are partially excreted by the kidneys, and so the neuromuscular block is prolonged in patients with renal failure(Option B, C & D)

questions.text: Among the commonly used local anesthetics, more cardiotoxic potential is observed in
questions.solution: Unintended intravascular injection of bupivacaine during regional anesthesia may produce severe cardiovascular toxicity, including left ventricular depression, atrioventricular heart block, and life-threatening arrhythmias such as ventricular tachycardia and fibrillation.

questions.text: Differentiating features of psoriatic arthritis from RA is?
questions.solution:
Psoriatic arthritis:

  • Psoriatic Arthropathy presents as a polyarthritis, where the distal IP joints of hands are commonly involved (unlike rheumatoid arthritis, where these are spared)
  • RA factor is negative.
  • Male and Females are equally affected
  • There is a strong genetic predisposition; family history of psoriasis is often present and almost 60% patients who have a concomitant sacroiliitis or spondylitis lesion are positive for HLA-B27.
  • HLA-Cw6 gene is also associated with the disorder.
  • Classic skin lesions and nail lesion help in diagnosis
  • The patient may present with one of several patterns of joint involvement (described by Wright and Mall)
    1. Arthritis of DIP joints
    2. Asymmetrical oligoarthritis: most common pattern
    3. Symmetrical polyarthritis similar to RA
    4. Axial involvement similar to ankylosing spondylitis
    5. Arthritis multilans where there is extensive destruction of finger joints
  • Hand may develop telescoping of IP joints, which is called Opera glass digits.
  • Swelling of fingers can result in sausage digts.
  • X ray of hand shows Pencil in cup deformity.
  • The drug of choice for psoriatic arthritis-Methotrexate
  • Treatment is by methotrexate, anti TNF agents (Etanercept and infliximab), and steroids.

questions.text: Runner's fracture occurs in which of the following bones?
questions.solution:
• Runner's fracture: Stress fracture of the distal fibula.
  • Bumper fracture: A fracture of the tibial plateau.
  • Toddler's fracture: A spiral fracture of the tibial shaft seen in toddlers due to twisting injury.
  • Pott's fracture: Bimalleolar ankle fracture.
  • Cotton's fracture: Trimalleolar ankle fracture.
  • Bosworth fracture: A fracture dislocation at ankle where fibula is trapped behind tibia resulting in irreducibility of the ankle by manipulation.
  • Massonneuve's fracture: Fracture of medial malleolus with fracture proximal third fibula.
  • Pilon fracture: It is a comminuted intra articular fracture of the distal end of tibia.
  • Tillaux fracture: This is avulsion of anterior tibial margin by the anterior inferior tibiofibular ligament (Salter Harris type III injury).

questions.text: Which of the following is the last secondary ossification centre to develop in the elbow?
questions.solution:
• There are six ossification centers around elbow which appear in a predictable sequence. CRITOE is a simple way to remember this.
    • C-Capitellum at 2 years
    • R-Radial head at 4 years
    • I-Internal (medial) epicondyle at 6 years
    • T-Trochlea at 8 years
    • O-Olecranon at 10 years
    • E-External (lateral) epicondyle at 12 years

questions.text: Which of the following shoulder examinations is a test for impingement?
questions.solution:
• Hawkin's test is performed by passively forward flexing the shoulder to 90 degrees and internally rotating the shoulder. If there is pain, then it indicates impingement syndrome.
  • Speed's test is used to examine for long head of biceps tendinitis. Forward flex the shoulder (60 degrees) against resistance while maintaining the elbow in extension and the forearm in supination - tenderness in the bicipital groove indicates bicipital tendinitis.
  • O'Brien's test is a test for SLAP tears of shoulder. Here, the shoulder is held in 90 degrees of forward flexion, 30 to 45 degrees of horizontal adduction and maximal internal rotation. Then, grab the patient's wrist and resist the patient's attempt to horizontally adduct and forward flex the shoulder.
  • Crank test - is another test for identifying SLAP lesion.

questions.text: While TNF-alpha inhibitors are the most commonly used biologic DMARDs, an IL-6 receptor antagonist has also been found to be effective in treating arthritis. An example of this drug class is:
questions.solution:
• One way to try and remember this is that the drug name contains the letter combination "IL". It is the only IL-6 receptor antagonist currently available, and has been found to be slightly superior to methotrexate as monotherapy for RA
  • Other biological used in RA are
    • Abatacept - This is "co-stimulation" modulator that inhibits T cell activation by binding to CD80 on the cell membrane of T cells.
    • Anakinra - This is an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It has not been found to be highly effective in treating RA
    • Rituximab - This is a chimeric monoclonal antibody against the CD20 antigen expressed on the surface of B cells
    • Tofactinib is a JAK inhibitor
    • Infliximab, Adalimumab and Etanercept are both TNF-alpha blockers.

questions.text: A 55-year old woman is noted to have a traumatic injury to her right thigh. Which of the following is most sensitive for the diagnosis of compartment syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Pain, typically severe and out of proportion to the injury, represents the first and most sensitive symptom of compartment syndrome. Pain, however, is extremely nonspecific. A better sign is pain on passive stretch, which by itself can be used as an indication to do fasciotomy.
  • Pulselessness represents a very late finding, and therefore, the finding of a palpable pulse should not exclude compartment syndrome in your differential diagnosis.

questions.text: Supracondylar humerus fracture is mostly caused by?
questions.solution:
• SUPRACONDYLAR FRACTURE OF THE HUMERUS - This is one of the most serious fractures in childhood as it is often associated with complications.
  • MECHANISM - The fracture is caused by a fall on an out-stretched hand. As the hand strikes the ground, the elbow is forced into hyperextension resulting in fracture of the humerus above the condyles.
  • The fracture line extends transversely through the distal metaphysis of humerus just above the condyles.
  • Types: A supracondylar fracture may be of extension or flexion type, depending upon the displacement of the distal fragment

questions.text: Which of the following is a GCT variant?
questions.solution:
Giant cell tumor variants:

  • These are those lesions which resemble GCT on microscopic examination because of presence of giant cells on microscopy.

The lesions include:

  • A - ABC and SBC
  • B - Brown's tumor of hyperparathyroidism
  • C - Chondroblastoma and Chondromyxoid fibroma

  • E - Epulis(Giant cell reparative granuloma)

questions.text: Gaenslen's test is used to identify which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Gaenslen's test is used for the diagnosis of sacroiliitis. The only cause of sacroilitis among the options is Ankylosing spondylosis. The signs and tests for sacroiliitis include:

1. Tenderness localized to posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) (as PSIS overlies SI joints)

2. SI side-to-side compression test: The patient is in the side lying position and the examiner's hands are placed over the upper part of the iliac crest, press- ing toward the floor. The movement causes strain in the SI joint. Positive test is indicated by pain in the SI joint.

3. Gaenslen's test: The patient lies on his or her back, the examiner maximally flexes the hip on the normal side (by pushing the knee towards patient chest) and extends the affected hip (by allowing it to fall over the side of the table). The test is considered positive if the patient complains of pain over the SI joint.

4. Pump handle test: The patient lies supine; the examiner grasps the affected side knee of the patients with one hand and flexes the knee and hip and forces it toward the opposite shoulder across the chest. Pain over involved SI joints indicates a positive test.

5. Patric test/FABER test: The test is performed by keeping the limb flexed, abducted and externally rotated (FABER). If pain is elicited on the ipsilateral side anteriorly, it is suggestive of hip joint pathology of same side. If pain is elicited on the contralateral side posteriorly around the SI joint, it is suggestive of pain arising from SI joint.

questions.text: 7 years old child presents with a lesion in upper tibia. X-ray shows radiolucent area with Codman's triangle and Sunray appearance.
questions.solution:

  • Osteosarcoma - most commonly involves long bone metaphyses, especially around the knee and at the proximal end of the humerus.
  • Ewing's sarcoma - most commonly involves the mid-diaphyseal region(common bones are tibia, fibula clavicle etc). About age Apley's writes - Osteosarcoma is said to occur predominantly in children and adolescents.

questions.text: Lauge Hansen classification system is used for?
questions.solution: The Lauge-Hansen classification system is used for the classification of ankle injuries based on injury mechanisms that have predictable patterns and imaging findings. Along with the Weber classification, these systems are useful tools for describing and classifying ankle injuries.

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady, after a history of fall, presents with pain in her left hip with external rotation and deformity of the hip. On examination, there was tenderness and broadening of the trochanter. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Intertrochanteric femur fracture: There will be swelling in the region of the hip, and the leg will be shortened and externally rotated. There is tenderness over the greater trochanter and broadening of the greater trochanter.
  • In case of neck femur fracture and subtrochanteric femur fracture, the GT will be normal.

questions.text: Unhappy triad of O'Donoghue is?
questions.solution:
• The unhappy triad was described by American orthopedic surgeon D H O'Donoghue, in 1950.
  • He described simultaneous occurrence of tear of ACL, MCL and medial meniscus tear when lateral force applied to knee while the foot is fixed to the ground.

questions.text: 3 year old child presented with progressive anemia, hepatosplenomegaly and osteomyelitis of jaw with pathological fracture. His x-rays show diffuse sclerosis of bones. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osteopetrosis(also known as Marble bone disease, Albers-Schonberg disease):

  • Defect is in bone resorption due to abnormal function of osteoclasts.
  • Defective bone resorption results in uniformly thickened dense bones, often without distinction between cortical and cancellous regions.
  • The bones are dense but brittle therefore known as marble bone disease.
  • Inheritance is both AD & AR. The AR form dies early in the life. The AD form is of milder variety.
  • Due to abnormal thickening of bone, there will be narrowing of cranial nerve foramina resulting in cranial N palsies causing blindness and deafness.
  • The medullary canal usually gets obliterated by bone deposition leading to bone marrow failure. This causes pancytopenia. Neutropenia manifests as recurrent infections especially mandibular osteomyelitis. Thrombocytopenia presents as easy bruising and bleeding. The anemia will be classically progressive as more and more of medullary canal gets filled up with bone.

questions.text: The X-ray findings seen in Osteomalacia are all of the following except
questions.solution:
• Radiographic findings in Osteomalacia
    1. The classical lesion of osteomalacia is the Looser zone, a thin transverse band of rarefaction in an otherwise normal-looking bone. These zones, seen especially in the shaft of long bones and the axillary edge of the scapula and are due to incomplete stress fractures which heal with callus lacking in calcium.
    2. Biconcave codfish vertebrae due to indentation on vertebral bodies by the intervertebral disk
    3. Trefoil or Champagne-glass pelvis
    4. Protrusio acetabuli.
  • Splaying of metaphysis is seen in rickets and not in osteomalacia.

choices.text: Fasciotomy can be performing after 24 hours of entrapment

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding crush syndrome except
questions.solution:
OPTION A - A late fasciotomy, when it is obvious that the muscles of that compartment must be dead, is only likely to cause a massive release of myoglobin, as well as potentially introducing infection into dead tissue.

Therefore, best NOT to perform a fasciotomy in cases where entrapment has been for over 12 hours.

  • Prolonged crushing of muscle leads to a reperfusion injury when the casualty is rescued (Option B)
  • This releases myoglobin and vasoactive mediators into the circulation. It also sequesters many liters of fluid, reducing the intravascular volume and resulting in renal vasoconstriction and ischemia. The myoglobinuria leads to renal failure from tubular obstruction. (Option C)
  • The treatment of crushed casualties should begin as soon as they are discovered. Rescuers must be alert to the presence of associated injuries.
  • Aggressive volume-loading of patients, preferably before extrication, is the best treatment. After provision of first aid and starting intravenous fluids the patient should be catheterized to measure urine output. In adults, a saline infusion of 1000-1500 mL per hour should be initiated. This should be continued until myoglobin is no longer detectable in the urine.
  • Mannitol administration can reduce the reperfusion component of this injury. Once a flow of urine is observed, a mannitol-alkaline diuresis of up to 8 liters per day should be maintained, keeping the urinary pH greater than 6.5.

Option B: Even though the infection subsides, radiological resolution takes 3 to 6 months to clear.

questions.solution:

  • They are life-threatening. Intussusception typically causes a strangulating bowel obstruction, which can progress to gangrene and perforation.
  • Intussusception is classified according to the site of the intussusceptum and intussuscipiens.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct statements regarding initial management of airway burn
Name the topical agent used in treatment for burn wound reduces cell mediated immunosuppression
questions.solution:
• Silver sulphadiazine cream (1%). This gives broad spectrum prophylaxis against bacterial colonisation and is particularly effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and also methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Silver nitrate solution (0.5%). Again, this is highly effective as a prophylaxis against Pseudomonas colonisation, but it is not as active as silver sulphadiazine cream against some of the gram-negative aerobes. The other disadvantage of this solution is that it needs to be changed or the wounds resoaked every 2-4 hours. It also produces black staining of all the furniture surrounding the patient.
  • Mafenide acetate cream. This is popular, especially in the United States, but is painful to apply. It is usually used as a 5% topical solution, but has been associated with metabolic acidosis.
  • Silver sulphadiazine and cerium nitrate. This is also a very useful burn dressing, especially for full-thickness burns. It induces a sterile eschar on the burned skin and has been shown in certain instances, especially in elderly patients, to reduce some of the cell-mediated immunosuppression that occurs in burns. Cerium nitrate forms a sterile eschar and is especially useful in treating burns when a conservative treatment option has been chosen. Cerium nitrate has also been shown to boost cell-mediated immunity in these patients.

questions.text: A 51-year-old male reports difficulty with urination and numbness in his bilateral buttocks. His symptoms began 12 hours ago. Which of the following statements about his condition is true?
questions.solution:
• Based on clinical profile patient is having cauda equine syndrome.
  • Cauda equina syndrome(CES) is caused by severe compression of lumbar and sacral nerve roots, occurs in approximately 2% of all patients with LDH.

Symptoms include:

  • Severe bilateral leg pain
  • Numbness in buttocks, back of legs and sole(Saddle anesthesia)
  • Perineal sensory deficit
  • Decreased rectal tone
  • Paralysis of muscles supplied by L5 and S1 nerve roots
  • Trendelenburg sign and gait is positive
  • Bowel/bladder symptoms(urinary retention early, then urine and bowel incontinence as the condition progresses)
  • Impotence
  • Babinski's reflex would be mute.

The imaging of choice is MRI. CT myelogram is indicated only if MRI is contraindicated(e.g., Presence of a pacemaker)

The treatment of choice is early surgery to decompress the cauda equina nerves.

Saddle anesthesia and bladder involvement may indicate a poor prognosis, however the prognosis is not related to patient's age.

questions.solution:
Protective factors for carcinoma breast include -

  • Breast feeding

questions.text: Which is the best method for the diagnosis of phyllodes tumour?
questions.solution:
• Excisional biopsy followed by careful pathologic review is the best method of diagnosing phyllodes tumor.
  • Phyllodes tumors are seen on mammography as round densities with smooth borders and are indistinguishable from fibroadenomas.
  • Ultrasonography may reveal a discrete structure with cystic spaces
  • Cytological analysis is unreliable in differentiating a low-grade phyllodes tumor from a fibroadenoma.

questions.text: According to the European hernia society classification, a primary indirect inguinal hernia of 3cm defect size would be classified as?
questions.solution:
The European Hernia Society has recently suggested a simplified system of:

  • primary or recurrent (P or R);
  • lateral, medial or femoral (L, M or F); lateral denotes for indirect hernia and medial denotes for direct hernia
  • defect size in fingerbreadths assumed to be 1.5 cm.

A primary, indirect, inguinal hernia with a 3-cm defect size would be PL2.

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for aneurysmal bleeding except?
questions.solution:
• Aneurysmal bleeding has an incidence of 10 - 15 per 100 000 population per year. Risk factors include
    • age,
    • female sex,
    • hypertension,
    • smoking,
    • cocaine abuse and
    • A family history with two first-degree relatives affected.

questions.text: A 25 year old male born to parents in a consanguineous marriage presents with the complaint of difficulty in night vision. Fundus examination is as shown in the picture. What is the most probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Retinitis pigmentosa, primary pigmentary retinal dystrophy is a hereditary disorder predominantly affecting the photoreceptor (rods more than the cones).

Inheritance of Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) may occur as:

  • Sporadic disorder (40-50%)
  • Inherited disorder
  • Autosomal dominant RP (adRP)
  • Autosomal recessive RP (arRP)
  • X-linked recessive (XLR)
  • Digenic inheritance is very rare

Symptoms include: Night blindness, delayed dark adaptation, loss of peripheral vision and complete loss of vision in severe cases.

• Visual loss plus red desaturation along with presence of RAPD indicate optic nerve dysfunction.
  • Fundus imaging is within normal limits with no disc edema or macular exudates, hence disease should be involving retro laminar portion of optic nerve.
  • Acute retrobulbar neuritis produces no ophthalmoscopically visible Changes, unless the lesion is near the lamina cribrosa when some signs of Papillitis may be seen with distension of the veins and attenuation of the Arteries.
  • If atrophic changes follow, the degeneration extends not only Towards the brain but also towards the eye.
  • In milder cases, pallor of the disc may be limited to the temporal side.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for development of Acanthamoeba Keratitis?
questions.solution:
Acanthamoebic keratitiscan be a devastating infection if not recognized early. Its occurrence is frequently associated with the wearing of soft contact lenses. The usual source of infection is the saline solution used to clean or store the lenses. It has also been seen to occur in noncontact lens wearers and may be related to swimming or bathing in contaminated water. There may be no antecedent trauma.

Tap water/ contaminated water/ contaminated saline solutions if used for lens washing/ storage predispose to infection.

questions.text:
A 37 year old patient with no significant systemic history reports to OPD with severe pain and lacrimation in both eyes with clinical imaging as depicted below: corneal ulcers with over hanging edge noted at periphery in cresenteric manner.

Which of the following statements regarding this condition is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Young patient, no systemic history, severe pain and characteristic marginal ulceration with over hanging edge: Pathgonomonic of Mooren’s Ulcer.

Etiology:

The exact underlying cause is unknown. Erosion is initiated by autoimmune lysis of the epithelium with consequent release of collagenolytic enzymes.

Symptoms: It is accompanied by severe and persistent neuralgic pain and lacrimation.

Signs:

  • It commences as one or more grey infiltrates, which break down forming small ulcers that spread and sooner or later coalesce.
  • The ulcer undermines the epithelium and superficial stromal lamellae at the advancing border, forming a whitish overhanging edge which is characteristic, while the base quickly becomes vascularized.
  • It rarely perforates but progresses with intermissions for months until eventually a thin nebula is formed over the whole cornea and sight is greatly diminished.
  • Bilateral involvement with severe pain and relentless progression ('malignant') is more common in young adults, while a milder, usually unilateral, less painful form is seen in elderly patients.

Mooren ulcer is a diagnosis of exclusion after all other systemic disorders predisposing to marginal ulceration are ruled out.

questions.text:

This is a case of nasal bone fracture.

The nasal bone fracture should be reduced immediately within 1-2 hours before edema starts. This is done using Walsham forceps.

If edema is already there, then wait for 7 days for the edema to subside and then reduce the fracture.

It is difficult to reduce a nasal fracture after 2 weeks because it heals by that time.

questions.text: A COVID 19 patient presents to emergency in a critical state with deranged vitals. The examination shows a blackish necrotic debris in the nasal cavity with necrosed skin of external nose. What is the best treatment of this patient?

  • Treatment of underlying diabetes, HIV, COVID, neutropenia or leukopenia
  • Posaconazole is also effective.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old farmer presents to OPD with complaints of redness, irritation and growth over the eye. Clinical imaging is as below.

Identify the lesion depicted in the image.
questions.solution:
Phlycten: nodular lesions situated near limbus

Pinguencula: degenerative nodular lesions in palpebral conjunctiva

Pannus: lymphocytic and vascular ingrowth into cornea

Pterygium Overview:

  • Definition: Pterygium, meaning 'a wing,' is a triangular growth of vascularized granulation tissue covered by conjunctiva that encroaches into the interpalpebral area of the eye.
  • Aetiopathogenesis: It is a degenerative condition of the subconjunctival tissue, characterized by avascularized granulation tissue that invades the cornea, destroying superficial stromal layers and Bowman's membrane. This condition is common in dry, sunny climates with sandy soils, possibly due to exposure to ultraviolet (UV) light. Localised stem cell deficiency is also a risk factor
  • Clinical Features:
    • Pterygium often follows a pinguecula.
    • Typically bilateral, commonly found on the nasal side of the eye.
    • Can impair vision due to induced astigmatism or progression into the pupillary area.
    • Induces astigmatism (with the rule) with corneal flattening along the axis of the pterygium.
    • Initially appears thick and vascular, but becomes thin, pale, and atrophic in later stages.
  • Differential Diagnosis: Pseudopterygium is similar but nonprogressive, can occur at any corneal limbus quadrant, and has adhesions to the adjacent lid and scar tissue anchoring it to the underlying surface.

Treatment:

  • Pterygium should be left alone unless it progresses toward the pupillary area, causes excessive astigmatism, restricts ocular motility, or is disfiguring.
  • Surgical removal involves:
    • Seizing the neck near the corneal margin with fixation forceps.
    • Raising and dissecting the pterygium from the cornea, starting from the apex.
    • Careful dissection to avoid going too deep.
    • Excising as much of the pterygium as possible.
    • Leaving a bare area of sclera at the edge of the cornea.
  • Recurrence can occur, and prevention methods include:
    • Postoperative therapy with mitomycin C drops (with associated complications).
    • Using an autoconjunctival graft or an amniotic membrane graft, suturing it at the limbus to cover the excision site.
    • For recurring pterygium extending towards the pupillary area, freeing the apex, excising the lesion, and inserting a lamellar graft over the affected area. MMC can be tried during surgery and post operative to reduce recurrence

This systematic summary provides concise information about pterygium, its clinical features, differential diagnosis, and treatment options.

questions.solution:

questions.text: Identify the given instrument
questions.solution:
Kocher dissector. This is used during a thyroidectomy to dissect the upper pole of the thyroid.

  • The instrument is blunt and therefore the surgeon is highly unlikely to inadvertently damage the superior thyroid artery or the external laryngeal nerve.
  • It is used to dissect the superior pedicle, the superior thyroid artery.
  • Once it has been isolated, the dissector is pushed under the pedicle.
  • A tie is then put through the eye of the dissector which at this stage doubles up as an aneurysm needle.
  • The pedicle is thus tied three times as close to the gland as possible.
  • With the dissector under the tied pedicle, a fine knife is now used to cut leaving two ties in the patient.
  • The presence of the dissector under the pedicle prevents any damage to the underlying structures.
  • Emil Theodor Kocher (1841-1917), Professor of Surgery at Berne, Switzerland, was awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine in 1909 for his work on the thyroid.
  • The first surgeon to be a Nobel Laureate.

questions.text: Which among the following is not the landmark commonly used for location of the facial nerve trunk?
questions.solution:
LOCATION OF THE FACIAL NERVE TRUNK

  • The main methods of facial nerve trunk localisation can be divided into antegrade and retrograde.
  • The former utilises anatomical landmarks to identify the nerve trunk after its exit from the stylomastoid foramen, which is then traced distally. Landmarks commonly used are:
    1. The inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. This is termed Conley's pointer (tragal pointer) and indicates the position of the facial nerve, which lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip
    2. The upper border of the posterior belly of the digastric muscle. Identification of this muscle not only helps to mobilise the parotid gland, but also exposes an area immediately superior, in which the facial nerve is usually located
    3. The squamotympanic fissure
    4. The styloid process (the nerve is superficial to it)
    5. The mastoid process can be drilled and the nerve identified more proximally.

questions.text: Below Image Shown Is seen in?
questions.solution:
Above given image is of HAAB'S STRIAE.

PCG in infancy presents with the classic triad of epiphora, photophobia, and blepharospasm. Until 3 years of age, elevated IOP causes the cornea to stretch, leading to increased corneal diameter and enlargement of the globe (buphthalmos). The corneal stretching produces Haab striae, or breaks in the Descemet membrane, and may lead to corneal edema and corneal opacification.

Vogt’s striae are vertical lines in the posterior stroma of Descemet’s membrane of the cornea. They disappear with pressure applied to the cornea.Vogt’s striae are a feature of keratoconus, but they are also found in healthy eyes.

Many people with Wilson disease have Kayser-Fleischer rings, which are greenish, gold, or brownish rings around the edge of the cornea.

Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is characterized by the deposition of a fibrillar material in the anterior segment of the eye.

Exfoliative material is deposited on the iris, ciliary region and capsule of the lens. Clinically these appear as flakes on the anterior capsule of the lens and the edge of the iris, and are particularly evident in the mid-peripheral region where the anterior capsule is rubbed upon by the iris; the axial region is usually free. Although the origin of this material is not precisely known, it probably arises from multiple sources as part of a generalized basement membrane disorder. Deposition of pseudoexfoliation material on the lens zonules may lead to zonular weakness. The anterior chamber angle is often narrow in patients with pseudoexfoliation, presumably as a result of anterior movement of the lens-iris diaphragm related to zonular weakness.

questions.text: What factor is associated with a higher risk of dislocation after total hip arthroplasty?
questions.solution:
Dislocation after total hip arthroplasty is a multifactorial problem.

Numerous risk factors may act independently or cumulatively to increase the risk of this complication. Previous hip surgery of any kind is associated with a twofold increased risk for dislocation.

Other risk factors include

  • Female gender,
  • Impaired mental status,
  • Inflammatory arthritis, and older age.

Numerous studies have shown a lower dislocation rate with a direct lateral approach, although surgical techniques such as capsular repair have significantly lowered the incidence of dislocation after using the posterior approach. Metal-on-metal bearings have been associated with other complications such as adverse tissue reactions but are often used with larger-diameter bearings, which pose a lower risk of dislocation.

Reference: Berry, D. J. (2001). PRIMARY TOTAL HIP ARTHROPLASTY. In M. W. Chapman (Ed.), Chapman's Orthopaedic Surgery (3rd ed., pp. 2769-2794). Lippincott Williams & Wilkins.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the ophthalmic outpatient department with gradual blurring of vision in the left eye. Slit lamp examination reveals fine stellate keratic precipitates and aqueous flare and a typical complicated posterior subcapsular cataract. No posterior synechiae were observed. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis, is a chronic non-granulomatous condition presenting as low-grade unilateral anterior inflammation. It is most commonly unilateral.

Patients with FHI are often asymptomatic for many years prior to presentation as, unlike with other anterior uveitides, they typically will have no pain, redness or photophobia.

Signs include:

  • Iris - Heterochromia and atrophy
  • Iris rubeosis
  • Posterior synechiae are absent
  • Stellate, grey - white keratic precipitates. Located diffusely over the entire corneal endothelium.
  • Anterior chamber - faint flare and mild cellular activity
  • Russell bodies - Tiny crystals may be present on the iris surface. These are aggregations of spherical immunoglobulin.
  • Koeppe nodules can be seen - may initially lead to a misdiagnosis of granulomatous uveitis.
  • Amsler sign - Prominent iris and angle vessels that bleed after paracentesis

Complications:

  • Cataract is extremely common - a posterior subcapsular morphology is seen initially
  • Glaucoma is typically a later manifestation

Treatment:

  • Long-term monitoring is indicated to detect glaucoma and other complications. The complications are treated accordingly.
  • Topical steroids may be used short-term for moderate severe exacerbations, but are generally not thought to be helpful in the management of chronic low-grade inflammation.

questions.text: The most common cause of this eye condition appears to be
questions.solution:
This is a case of Right eye anterior staphyloma.

Staphyloma is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak point of the eye.

Acquired anterior staphyloma occurs subsequent to corneal perforation, usually following untreated or non-responding infective keratitis. Anterior staphylomas are rarely observed in patients with Peters anomaly.

When the cornea perforates, the iris plugs the wound and a pseudocornea forms over the iris. It is unable to withstand the intraocular pressure and thus, progressively protrudes.

The treatment of anterior staphyloma usually involves evisceration of the affected eye and sclerokeratoplasty.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with suspected diagnosis of suppurative labyrinthitis. A positive Rinne test and a positive fistula sign were recorded on initial examination. What would be the expected finding on repeating the Rinne test?
questions.solution: The patient was earlier having labyrinthine fistula. Because of no treatment, he developed dead labyrinth. A negative fistula sign in this case indicates a dead labyrinth which implies severe sensorineural hearing loss. In such cases a false negative Rinne's test is most likely.

questions.text: Aim of mastoid surgery in unsafe CSOM which should receive first priority is:
questions.solution:
UNSAFE CSOM- ATTICOANTRAL CSOM:

  • Hallmark of this disease is the presence of CHOLESTEATOMA.

Primary Acquired Cholesteatoma (most common type):

This type of Cholesteatoma originates from RETRACTION POCKETS Retraction Pockets are most common in Pars Flaccida.

This theory is called WITTMACKS THEORY.

Chief complaints :

Ear discharge- scanty, foul smelling (due to bone erosion) and blood stained (due to granulation formation).

Hearing loss is mostly conductive, sometimes mixed (CHL+ SNHL)

Treatment :

Surgery is called MRM (Modified Radical Mastoidectomy) also called as TYMPANOMASTOID EXPLORATION.

Main aim of MRM is to make ear safe.

After making adequate clearance of cholesteatoma, we remove the posterior wall of EAC to open the mastoid cavity into EAC.

Hence, MRM is a classical example of canal wall down surgery (CWD).

Canal wall means posterior wall of EAC and down means removed.

questions.text: A 43 year old male patient is suffering from recurrent episodes of vertigo, hearing loss and tinnitus for last 3 years. The episode has nausea and vomiting along with vertigo. The episode settles in few hours only. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
MENIERES DISEASE-ENDOLYMPHATIC HYDROPS:

  • In Meniere's disease, there is a rise in endolymph volume due to poor absorption by endolymphatic sac.

It is mostly unilateral disease. →I/L Migraine

  • Slightly more common in males. 3rd to 4th decade
  • Etiology is unknown.
  • It is an episodic disease. I/L Migraine

During Episode:

  • Episode has 3 features
    1. Tinnitus- it is the first symptom.
    2. Vertigo (With nausea, vomiting)
    3. Hearing loss.

+/- Fullness in ear

In between episodes

  1. Tinnitus may persist.
  2. Patient hears loud sounds as more loud. This is called Recruitment phenomenon
  3. Patients can get vertigo on hearing loud sounds. This is called Tullio's phenomenon
  4. Patient has a dislike for noisy areas.
  5. Patients hear the same sound in 2 frequencies. This is called Diplacusis

FEW YEARS LATER

Cochlear damage starts due to high endolymphatic pressure. (Glaucoma of ear).

This leads to hearing loss in between episodes also. This will lead to

Fluctuating hearing loss Meniere's disease causes low Frequency SNHL in early stages.

Investigations

  1. PTA (pure tone audiometry) - unilateral SNHL (Low frequencies SNHL in early stages). This will lead to a rising audiogram.
  2. RECRUITMENT PHENOMENON is positive.
  3. SHORT INCREMENT SENSITIVITY INDEX (SISI)
  4. Electrocochleography(ECOCHG)- SP:AP Ratio>30% (used for diagnostic workup of MENIERES disease.)

TREATMENT:

  1. During episode- anti vertigo medications. Eg- prochlorperazine, cinnarizine.
  2. In between episode- Acetazolamide (diuretic)

If episodes of vertigo become more frequent and disabling Further treatment options Think of 2 scenarios.

  1. Residual hearing is present-
    1. VESTIBULAR NEURECTOMY- Transect the vestibular branch of 8thnerve to a control vertigo symptoms.
    2. MENIET DEVICE - Home based therapy: Everyday It is Intermittent low pressure pulse therapy for inner ear.
    3. ENDOLYMPHATIC SAC DECOMPRESSION SURGERY
  2. If no residual hearing is there -
    1. Transtympanic Gentamycin Injection
    2. Surgical Labyrinthectomy.

questions.text: Subretinal demarcation line or watershed line is seen in

Signs-

questions.text:
Choose the correction option form the following for given statements:
Assertion: Heliox is used for ventilation in laryngospasm
Reason: Heliox has a Reynolds number > 2000.
questions.solution:
• Heliox is a mixture of 70% helium and 30% oxygen. Helium decreases the density of gas mixture leading to less turbulent and more laminar airflow which is desirable in laryngospasm.
  • When Reynolds number is < 2000 flow is likely to be laminar and when > 2000 flow is likely to be turbulent.
  • Hence Heliox has a Reynolds number < 2000.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man known to have COPD is admitted with severe respiratory distress. What is the flow rate required to deliver 28% oxygen through a venturi mask?
questions.solution:
The FiO2 delivered by venturi mask depends on the oxygen flow rate and the amount of air entrained. The amount of air entrained depends on the venturi mask adaptors. There are slits in the venturi mask adaptors, which become smaller or larger depending on whether a high or lower FIO2 is required. These slits are designed to entrain air from the environment. Therefore, the set oxygen flow and the entrained air together meet the inspiratory flow requirement of the patient

Reference: Al-Shaikh B, Stacey S, Eds. Fixed performance devices. In: Essentials of anaesthetic equipment, 3rd ed. London, UK: Churchill Livingstone, Elsevier, 2007; Chapter 6: 89-91.

questions.text: If you administer spinal anaesthesia with all the three spinal needles given in the image below, which one will provide you the most vigorous CSF flow?
questions.solution:
In the given image,

A- Quincke needle

B- Whitacre needle

C- Sprotte needle

The Sprotte is a side-injection needle with a long opening. It has the advantage of more vigorous CSF flow compared with similar gauge needles. However, this can lead to a failed block if the distal part of the opening is subarachnoid (with free flow CSF), the proximal part is not past the dura, and the full dose of medication is not delivered.

Quincke needle is a cutting needle with end injection.

The Whitacre and other pencil-point needles have rounded points and side injection which markedly decrease the incidence of post dural puncture headache.

questions.text: You are performing an axillary brachial plexus block using the instrument given below. At 0.5 mA current, you can see the motor response. Which is the next best step?
questions.solution:
• Given image is that of a peripheral nerve stimulator used for performing nerve stimulator guided blocks of peripheral nerves.
  • Occurrence of a motor response at 0.5 mA (0.1 ms) indicates needle-nerve contact or intraneural needle placement.
  • Such an occurrence should prompt caution. The practitioner should stop advancing the needle, withdraw the needle by 1 mm, and inject 1 mL of local anesthetic (assuming the opening pressure is less than 15 psi) to determine the needle tip position and adjust the needle and injection process accordingly.

questions.text: Figure shows the pin index safety system in cylinders. Match the index to the correct gas from the table.
questions.solution:
• The pin-index system is a safety feature, designed to prevent wrong connection of a cylinder containing one substance to a delivery system of different substance
  • For example, attaching a nitrous oxide cylinder to the oxygen delivery system would produce 100% N2O, while you may believe you are attempting to give 100% O2. This will cause lethal damage to the patient. To prevent such accidents, PISS (pin-index safety system) was introduced
  • The system works by having a series of holes drilled into the valve on top of the cylinder in particular positions for each gas - these correspond to pins on the anesthesia machine, which prevent connection unless the pins fit into the respective holes.

Reference: OSCE's in Anesthesia (William Simpson) pg. 110

choices.text: Has a decreased risk of disconnection

questions.text: Compared to the Mapleson A system, the circle system
questions.solution:
Advantages of the circle system include economy (low fresh gas flow rates, decreased use of volatile agents), conservation of heat and humidity, and decreased operating-room pollution. Disadvantages of circle system include greater size, decreased portability, increased risk of disconnection, and increased resistance to patient breathing.

Reference: Lippincott's ANESTHESIA REVIEW: 1,001 QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS Paul Sikka, MD, PhD

questions.text: A 47 year old with history of smoking for last 10 years has presented with hoarseness of voice for last 3 weeks. The fibreoptic laryngoscopy image has been shown in the given image. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In vast majority of cases, laryngeal cancer originates in the glottic region. Free edge and upper surface of vocal cord in its anterior and middle third is the most frequent site

spread. Locally, the lesion may spread anteriorly to anterior commissure and then to the opposite cord; posteriorly to vocal process and arytenoid region; upward to ventricle and false cord; and downwards to subglottic region. Vocal cord mobility is unaffected in early stages.

Fixation of vocal cord indicates spread of disease to thyroarytenoid muscle and is a bad prognostic sign.

There are few lymphatics in vocal cords and nodal metastases are practically never seen in cordal lesions unless the disease spreads beyond the region of membranous cord.

symptoms. Hoarseness of voice is an early sign because lesions of cord affect its vibratory capacity. It is because of this that glottic cancer is detected early.

questions.text: Physical examination of a 45-year-old man who had been stabbed in the back of the shoulder shows a deep wound penetrating into the quadrangular space of the shoulder, causing bleeding from the severed blood vessels there. Which of the following neural structures is most likely damaged as well?
questions.solution: The quadrangular space of the shoulder is an important passageway allowing the posterior humeral circumflex vessels and their companion axillary nerve to pass from the axilla to the posterior aspect of the shoulder. The neurovascular bundle runs across the surgical neck of the humerus to enter the quadrangular space. The space itself (sometimes termed the lateral axillary hiatus) is formed by four structures: teres major, teres minor, long head of the triceps, surgical neck of the humerus. The vessels contribute to the collateral network around the shoulder. The axillary nerve supplies the teres minor and deltoid muscles and a cutaneous area on the superolateral aspect of the arm (i.e., the skin overlying the lower aspect of the deltoid).

questions.text: What part of the ischioanal (ischiorectal) fossa extends deep to the sacrotuberal ligament?
questions.solution: The ischioanal fossa is a space found on both sides of the anal canal. It is bounded laterally by the obturator internus, superiorly by the pelvic diaphragm, and medially by the pelvic diaphragm and anus. It is the area that is lateral to the anal canal and inferior to the pelvic diaphragm. The anterior recesses are the parts of the ischioanal fossa that extend above the perineal membrane, and the posterior recesses extend deep to the sacrotuberal membrane and superior to the gluteus maximus. The genital hiatus is the place where the pelvic diaphragm splits to allow the urethra/vagina and anus to pass through. The pudendal canal travels from the lesser sciatic foramen, where its contents enter the perineum. It contains the internal pudendal artery, internal pudendal vein, and pudendal nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following veins drain into the structures marked A?
questions.solution:
The structures marked A are the right and left brachiocephalic veins. The left superior intercostal vein drains into the left brachiocephalic vein.

Tributaries of the brachiocephalic vein:

  • Left and right internal thoracic veins
  • Left and right inferior thyroid veins
  • Left superior intercostal vein drains into the left brachiocephalic vein.

The right superior intercostal vein drains into the azygos vein.

questions.text: Which chamber's anterior wall forms most of the sternocostal surface of the heart?
questions.solution: The heart has three important surfaces: an anterior surface, a diaphragmatic surface, and a pulmonary surface. The anterior surface, or sternocostal surface, is mostly made up of the right ventricle. The diaphragmatic surface is mostly the left ventricle, but a little bit of the right ventricle sits on the diaphragm as well. Finally, the pulmonary surface, which is on the left, is mostly made up of the left ventricle.

questions.text: Of the following, which is derived from endoderm?
questions.solution: The epithelium of the pharynx is epithelium that is derived from the endodermal epithelium of the primitive gut. The epithelium of the lower part of the anal canal is derived from ectoderm, while the upper part is lined with endoderm. The boundary between endodermal and ectodermal lining is called the pectinate line

questions.text: The extensor expansion of the ring finger receives tendons from all of the following EXCEPT:

The dorsal and palmar interosseus muscles and the lumbricals are inserting into these extensor expansions. Extensor carpi ulnaris inserts on the medial side of the base of the 5th metacarpal it is not inserting near the extensor expansions.

questions.text: A man has a herniated intervertebral disk between the fourth and fifth lumbar vertebrae. If this disk compresses the spinal nerve in the intervertebral foramen immediately posterior to this disk, which spinal nerve would be affected?
questions.solution: If a disc herniates between L4 and L5, it will be impinging on the L5 spinal nerve. This is because the L4 nerve lies immediately below the L4 pedicle, above the herniating disc. However, the L5 nerve roots are already proceeding laterally toward the L5 intervertebral foramen, so it is usually caught by the herniating L4/5 disc. In the cervical region, the spinal nerves emerge above the vertebrae of the same number, while in the thoracic, lumbar and sacral region the spinal nerves emerge below the vertebrae of the same number. As well, cervical roots course nearly directly laterally to exit. So, although the result is similar (herniating discs compress the lower numbered vertebrae of the pair), the reasons are different for cervical regions and lower levels. Make sure to keep this difference straight, because it's an important one to remember!

choices.text: Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib

questions.text: Which among the following is incorrect regarding Sibsons's fascia?
questions.solution:
Sibson's fascia is attached to the inner border of the 1st rib, not the 2nd rib.

Sibson's fascia (suprapleural membrane) serves as a plane of separation between the lower neck and the thorax and covers the apical part of the lung. It is attached to the inner border of the 1st rib and posteriorly to the anterior border of the transverse process of the C7 vertebra.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought in with coughing, and you are told by her mother that she had been playing with some beads and had apparently aspirated one (gotten it into her airway). Where would you expect it to most likely be?
questions.solution: There are several reasons why inhaled objects will be more likely to enter the right lung instead of the left lung. First, the carina, a ridge-like structure at the bifurcation of the trachea, is set a little towards the left. So, there is a more direct path for objects to fall to the right. Also, the right bronchus is shorter, wider, and more vertical than the left bronchus. All of these factors mean that an inhaled object will enter the right main bronchus. It would be almost impossible for a bead to get lodged in the terminal bronchiole of the right lung - that is a very small space!

questions.text: A boy fell onto a sharp object and cut his deep radial nerve as it emerged from the supinator muscle. The artery joining it at this point was also injured. The injured artery is the:
questions.solution: The deep radial nerve emerges from the supinator muscle and runs in the deep layer of the posterior forearm. It runs next to the posterior interosseous artery, which, along with the anterior interosseous artery, is a branch of the common interosseous artery. The common interosseous artery comes off the ulnar artery to give these two branches that supply the deep arm on the anterior and posterior sides. The ulnar and radial arteries are branches of the brachial artery that run down the ulnar and radial sides of the anterior arm.

questions.text: Which of the following is correctly paired?
questions.solution: The obturator nerve provides motor innervation to the adductor longus, adductor brevis, gracilis, obturator externus and ischiocondylar part of adductor magnus muscle. Its cutaneous distribution covers the skin of the proximal part of the medial thigh, as well as the hip and knee joints.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is likely to be paralyzed when bed ridden stroke patient is asked to protrude the tongue?
questions.solution:
The genioglossus is an extrinsic muscle of the tongue. It is a large, thick muscle, which contributes significantly to the shape of the tongue.

  • Attachments: Arises from the mandibular symphysis. It inserts onto the body of the hyoid bone and the entire length of the tongue.
  • Function: Protrusion ('sticking the tongue out') and depression of the tongue. When both the right and left genioglossus contract they protrude the anterior part of the tongue out of the mouth in the midline.
  • Innervation: Hypoglossal nerve.
  • Blood supply: Lingual artery with contributions from the tonsillar artery.

questions.text: A patient presents with periorbital edema, eyelid erythema, chemosis, ptosis and high-grade fever with spikes. Patient has a history of tonsillitis and otitis media. Examination shows paralysis of extra ocular muscles, loss of pupillary reflex and loss of corneal reflex. Visual acuity is preserved. What is most likely involved with this disease?
questions.solution:
The marked arrow in the CT scan shows cavernous sinus.

The given scenario explains paralysis of extra ocular muscles, loss of pupillary reflex and loss of corneal reflex. It means there is paralysis of the oculomotor nerve, trochlear nerve, abducens nerve and ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve, though the optic nerve is spared. This suggests infection of cavernous sinus which is marked above.

High fever with spikes explains Picket fence fever.

Cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST) is a rare, life-threatening disorder that can complicate facial infection, sinusitis, orbital cellulitis, pharyngitis, or otitis or following traumatic injury or surgery, especially in the setting of a thrombophilic disorder. Early recognition of cavernous sinus thrombosis which, often presents with fever, headache, eye findings such as periorbital swelling, and ophthalmoplegia, is critical for a good outcome. Despite modern treatment with antibiotics and anticoagulation, the risk of long-term sequelae, such as decreased vision, diplopia, and stroke, remains significant.

questions.text: Which branch of facial nerve supplies muscles of facial expression?
questions.solution:
General

Cranial nerve seven (CN VII) is responsible for both efferent and afferent modalities in the head and neck including:

  1. Branchial motor fibers that innervate:
  2. muscles of "facial expression"
  3. stylohyoid muscle
  4. posterior belly of digastric
  5. stapedius
  6. occipitofrontalis
  7. Special sensory fibers for taste from the anterior 2/3 of tongue
  8. General sensation from the external auditory canal and auricle
  9. Preganglionic parasympathetic fibers innervating the submandibular, sublingual, lacrimal glands as well as the mucous membranes of the nose, palate, and oropharynx

questions.text: A neurological examination of a 51-year old woman indicated that she had a loss of pain and temperature sense on the right side of her body, a decreased sense of taste on the left side and hoarseness of voice when speaking. She also complained of dizziness and nausea.Which of the following arteries may be occluded in this patient?
questions.solution:
The symptoms described in the question suggest a lesion in the brainstem, specifically affecting the lateral medulla.

This is known as Wallenberg syndrome or lateral medullary syndrome. The PICA supplies the lateral medulla, and its occlusion can result in the symptoms described, including loss of pain and temperature sensation on the opposite side of the body, decreased taste sensation on the same side of the tongue, hoarseness, dizziness, and nausea. Therefore, the occlusion of the Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA) is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms.

questions.text: Where the marked structure is located?

9 year old boy fell from building rushed into emergency. CT scan reveals skull base fracture along the apex of the petrous bone involving the Dorello's canal. Which of the following cranial nerves is susceptible to injury?
questions.solution: The abducens nerve arises from the abducens nucleus in the pons of the brainstem. It exits the brainstem at the junction of the pons and the medulla. It then enters the subarachnoid space and pierces the dura mater to travel in an area known as Dorello's canal.

questions.text: Following an emergency appendectomy your patient complained of having paraesthesia (numbness) of the skin at the pubic region. The most likely nerve that has been injured during the operation is:
questions.solution: The iliohypogastric nerve is a branch of the lumbar plexus. It provides sensory innervation to the skin of the lower abdominal wall, upper hip and upper thigh. This is the region where the patient is experiencing paraesthesia, so this nerve must be injured. The genitofemoral nerve is another nerve from the lumbar plexus. It provides sensory innervation to the skin of the anterior scrotum or labia majora and upper medial thigh. The subcostal nerve is the ventral primary ramus of T12-it is the equivalent of an intercostal nerve at a higher thoracic level. It provides sensory innervation to the anterolateral abdominal wall, but in an area superior to the pubic region. A spinal nerve would not have been injured in the operation. Remember-the spinal nerve is just that small segment of nerve that exists once the dorsal and ventral rootlets come together, before the dorsal and ventral primary rami branch off. In any case, the T9 and T10 dermatomes are superior to the area where the patient is experiencing paraesthesia.

questions.text: The normal pattern of venous and lymphatic drainage of the superficial tissues of the anterior abdominal wall is arranged around a horizontal plane. Above that plane, drainage is in a cranial direction; below the plane drainage is in a caudal direction. This reference plane corresponds to:
questions.solution: Zone B represents level of umbilicus and the umbilicus is an important landmark for venous and lymphatic drainage of the abdominal wall. Above the umbilicus, lymphatics drain into the axillary lymph nodes and the venous blood drains into the superior epigastric vein, which drains to the internal thoracic vein. Below the umbilicus, lymphatics drain into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes, while venous blood drains into the inferior epigastric vein and the external iliac vein.

questions.text: A surgeon has planned for a biopsy procedure for a supraglottic lesion. Before the procedure, he placed a cotton soaked in Xylocaine in the Pyriform Sinus region. Which nerve is being anesthetized?
questions.solution: The superior laryngeal nerve, a branch of a vagus nerve produces two branches: the internal laryngeal nerve (its sensory branch) which supplies sensory fibers to the laryngeal mucosa, and the external laryngeal nerve (its motor branch) which innervates the cricothyroid muscle. Local anesthetic injections to block the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN) can anesthetize the supraglottic region, down to the bottom of the epiglottis, and block the cricothyroid muscle, which relaxes the vocal cords.

questions.text: In a postoperative intensive care unit, 5 patients developed postoperative wound infection on the same wound. The best method to prevent cross infection occurring in other patients in the same ward is to:
questions.solution:
Hand hygiene is a way of cleaning one's hands that substantially reduces potential pathogens (harmful microorganisms) on the hands. Hand hygiene is considered a primary measure for reducing the risk of transmitting infection among patients and health care personnel.

Hand hygiene procedures include the use of alcohol-based hand rubs (containing 60%-95% alcohol) and hand washing with soap and water. For surgical procedures, perform a surgical hand scrub before putting on sterile surgeon's gloves. For routine dental examinations and nonsurgical procedures, use an alcohol-based hand rub or use water and plain or antimicrobial soap specific for health care settings. Unless hands are visibly soiled (e.g. dirt, blood, body fluids), an alcohol-based hand rub is preferred over soap and water in most clinical situations.

Hand hygiene should be performed in the following situations:

  • Before and after treating each patient (e.g., before and after gloving).
  • After touching with bare hands instruments, equipment, materials, and other objects that are likely to be contaminated by blood, saliva, or respiratory secretions.
  • Before leaving the dental treatment area.
  • When hands are visibly soiled.
  • Before regloving and after removing gloves that are torn, cut, or punctured.

questions.text: Where is the epithelium shown in the image found?
questions.solution:
• The image shown in the image is transitional epithelium.
  • It lines the major part of urinary passage hence; it is also called urothelium.
  • Basal cells are cuboidal and rest on basal lamina.
  • Cells of upper layer are polygonal.
  • Cells of the most superficial layer are dome shaped/ umbrella shaped and more eosinophilic due to presence of plaque. Few are binucleated cells.
  • Location: renal pelvis and calyces of kidney, Ureter, Urinary bladder, Part of urethra.
  • Function:
    • It provides the ability of distension of the urinary bladder.
    • It acts as a barrier because of the presence of occluding junctions and intramembranous plaque.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice B (Gallbladder): The gallbladder is lined by simple columnar epithelium with microvilli, which facilitates absorption and concentration of bile. It does not contain transitional epithelium, making this choice incorrect.

Choice C (Duodenum): The duodenum has a simple columnar epithelium with goblet cells and microvilli, which aids in nutrient absorption. Additionally, it contains Brunner's glands in the submucosa, which secrete alkaline mucus. Since transitional epithelium is absent in the duodenum, this choice is incorrect.

Choice D (Trachea): The trachea is lined by pseudostratified columnar ciliated epithelium with goblet cells, which functions in mucus production and ciliary clearance of inhaled particles. This type of epithelium is structurally and functionally different from transitional epithelium, making this choice incorrect.

Key Takeaway

Transitional epithelium (urothelium) is found in the renal pelvis, ureters, bladder, and parts of the urethra, where it allows for distension and serves as a barrier to prevent urine leakage.

Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transitional_epithelium

questions.text: Among the given intravenous induction agent, which is an imidazole compound?
questions.solution:
• Etomidate:
    • IV anaesthetic agent, introduced in 1973.
    • A carboxylated imidazole (five-membered ring containing three carbon atoms and two nitrogen atoms) compound presented in 35% propylene glycol; pH is 8.1. 75% bound to plasma proteins after injection.
  • Midazolam hydrochloride.
    • Benzodiazepine, used for sedation, premedication and induction of anaesthesia. Has also been used for status epilepticus.
    • Water-soluble at pH < 4 due to its open imidazole ring (five-membered ring containing carbon and nitrogen atoms); it becomes highly lipid-soluble at body pH due to ring closure (an example of structural isomerism), resulting in rapid onset of action following iv administration.

questions.text: CECT scan of 13 year old male patient with Angiofibroma shows the tumor involving nasopharynx, nose and occupying the pterygopalatine fossa. What is the Radkowski tumour staging of this patient?

Radkowski staging of Angiofibroma

Stage

IA - limited to nasopharynx and nose

IB - extension into one or more than one sinus

IIA - minimal extension into pterygopalatine fossa

IIB - full occupation of pterygopalatine fossa with or without erosion of orbital bones

IIC - extending Infratemporal Fossa

IIIA - erosion of skull base with minimal intracranial invasion

IIIB - extensive intracranial invasion with or without cavernous sinus invasion

questions.text: The given image is of a CO2 laser assisted surgical procedure done in a case of bilateral abductor palsy. What is the name of this surgical procedure?

  • Done for bilateral abductor palsy.

Woodman's operation is arytenoidectomy by open approach.

Type 1 thyroplasty is done in the case of bilateral adductor palsy.

Type 2 thyroplasty is done for bilateral abductor palsy but quality of voice is not good.

questions.text: Which of the following is a tracheoesophageal puncture device used for post laryngectomy vocal rehabilitation?

questions.text: In Plummer-Vinson syndrome, the region involved is:

questions.text: The ideal management of Juvenile papilloma of larynx is
questions.solution:
Management of Juvenile papilloma of larynx -

  • Microlaryngoscopy and CO2laser excision avoiding injury to vocal ligament.
  • Recurrence is common and procedure needs to be repeated several times.
  • In the absence of CO2 laser - tumour removed under microscope with cup forceps or a debrider.

Medical therapies - can be used as adjuvants.

  • Interferon alpha-2a has shown promising results but has several side effects including fever, chills, myalgia, arthralgia, headache, loss of weight and suppression of bone marrow.
  • 13-cis-retinoic acid has also been used. This too has several side effects.

questions.text: The statement not true about Laryngeal Web is

Laryngeal webs are congenital with the glottis being the most common site. The cry is hoarse as the vocal cords are affected.

Treatment depends on the thickness of the web.

questions.text: Mid tracheostomy is done over?
questions.solution:
MID TRACHEOSTOMY

  • The preferred method
  • Done through the II or III tracheal ring and would entail division of the thyroid isthmus (lies against II, III and IV tracheal rings) or its retraction upwards or downwards to expose this part of trachea

LOW TRACHEOSTOMY

  • Done below the level of isthmus.
  • Trachea is deep at this level and close to several large vessels and tracheostomy tube can impinge on suprasternal notch.

HIGH TRACHEOSTOMY

  • Done above the level of thyroid isthmus
  • Can cause subglottic stenosis and is always avoided.
  • Only indication for high tracheostomy is carcinoma of larynx
